text: Hi friends! Question for you: What are your feelings on the difference between “staff writer” vs “content writer,” as job titles?

elements.text: Hi friends! Question for you: What are your feelings on the difference between “staff writer” vs “content writer,” as job titles?

text: I feel "staff writer" involves a more generic, catch-all role as opposed to "content writer" which involves specific projects.

elements.text: I feel "staff writer" involves a more generic, catch-all role as opposed to "content writer" which involves specific projects.

text: Interesting! Re: “staff writer,” I read it one of two ways: 1) distinction between employee and freelancer; 2) as an expert writer who is at a very high level of their craft—I work for a software company and “staff” is often used in engineering or design to designate the highest level of an individual contributor--e.g. “Staff Software Engineer” would be an extremely experienced, in some cases director-level, individual contributor.

elements.text: Interesting! Re: “staff writer,” I read it one of two ways: 1) distinction between employee and freelancer; 2) as an expert writer who is at a very high level of their craft—I work for a software company and “staff” is often used in engineering or design to designate the highest level of an individual contributor--e.g. “Staff Software Engineer” would be an extremely experienced, in some cases director-level, individual contributor.

text:
I am VERY much an advocate for “staff writer”. A Staff Writer is a permanent member of a creative team. They will build expertise and sources and mastery the longer they stay around. And it lets the audience know that we take that seriously!

“Content writer” is like saying “Food cooker” or “House builder”. It’s a bit redundant.

elements.text:
I am VERY much an advocate for “staff writer”. A Staff Writer is a permanent member of a creative team. They will build expertise and sources and mastery the longer they stay around. And it lets the audience know that we take that seriously!

“Content writer” is like saying “Food cooker” or “House builder”. It’s a bit redundant.

text:
i see "content writer" as referring to a writer who produces web copy, blog posts, etc. - as opposed to a novelist or PR writer or internal comms writer or other types of writers. so i don't see it as redundant at all.

"staff writer" could be a journalist, TV writer, etc.

"content writer" is more likely to be used in a business setting.

if you're concerned about attracting the right types of candidates, i would research job postings and note the difference between the 2 types of titles. you don't want to attract the wrong candidates (and miss out on great candidates) with a misleading title.

text: Crack imposter syndrome and chat with them on Twitter and LinkedIn. I became friends with all our industry analysts, experts, and influencers. That and featured them as influencers in an infographic!

elements.text: Crack imposter syndrome and chat with them on Twitter and LinkedIn. I became friends with all our industry analysts, experts, and influencers. That and featured them as influencers in an infographic!

text:
• mostly amazed at how generous people are to begin with. honestly, you can be pretty bad at outreach and _still_ get a decent response rate.
• if you can't get a warm intro to someone, finding a "warm community" helps. people who are active in a slack community, facebook group, etc., may be easiest to reach and build a relationship with there (vs. going straight for the one-on-one email).
• agency/consultant/freelancer types are usually up for it more than in-house folks, who are less concerned with generating leads or earning backlinks (always exceptions, but i try to adjust my pitch accordingly---an SEO at Amazon does not care about getting a backlink).
• the people who will give you the most time and best ideas are usually the "up and coming" marketers. the only semi-reliable way to find those is to see who the Marketing Famous people follow/retweet/etc. (i've also had success just asking directly for names of others i should reach out to.)
• avoid asking intro-level questions. experts are there to add depth and contrast to best practices, not to supply them. do your homework beforehand and ask about the things you couldn't figure out on your own.
• loop them into the bigger conversation: if you've already gotten an answer from Famous Marketer 1, ask Famous Marketer 2 what they think about that opinion. that gives you some credibility, ensures you're asking about a topic that interests a veteran, and results in some solid back-and-forth dialogue for the resulting content.

elements.text: mostly amazed at how generous people are to begin with. honestly, you can be pretty bad at outreach and
still
get a decent response rate.

if you can't get a warm intro to someone, finding a "warm community" helps. people who are active in a slack community, facebook group, etc., may be easiest to reach and build a relationship with there (vs. going straight for the one-on-one email).

agency/consultant/freelancer types are usually up for it more than in-house folks, who are less concerned with generating leads or earning backlinks (always exceptions, but i try to adjust my pitch accordingly---an SEO at Amazon does not care about getting a backlink).

the people who will give you the most time and best ideas are usually the "up and coming" marketers. the only semi-reliable way to find those is to see who the Marketing Famous people follow/retweet/etc. (i've also had success just asking directly for names of others i should reach out to.)

avoid asking intro-level questions. experts are there to add depth and contrast to best practices, not to supply them. do your homework beforehand and ask about the things you couldn't figure out on your own.

loop them into the bigger conversation: if you've already gotten an answer from Famous Marketer 1, ask Famous Marketer 2 what they think about that opinion. that gives you some credibility, ensures you're asking about a topic that interests a veteran, and results in some solid back-and-forth dialogue for the resulting content.

text: Hi all! :wave: A question on GDPR. I'm currently seeing a big chunk of leads getting attributed to direct traffic (it's not the homepage url but a /register page people are unlikely to type out). My understanding is that is this due to the folks who don't accept GDPR cookies. Has anyone faced this issue? How do you handle those leads?
